text:
Caption UConn Women: Best Ever (Current Edition) Don McPeak / USA Today Sports So, who is the best player in college basketball? Breanna Stewart is one of the best ever. UConn has her and no one else does.Stewie is the only player to be honored as Final Four most outstanding player three times. She was selected as the Associated Press player of the year in each of the past two seasons. She is as lethal as she is funny.She just returned from a tour of Europe with USA Basketball, where as the only college player on the team, playing alongside Brittney Griner, Candace Parker, Angel McCoughtry, Elena Delle Donne and Sue Bird, she played a nice role in the four straight wins Geno Auriemma toasted in Spain, Italy and the Czech Republic.Stewie comes into the season with 1,960 points, 11th all-time at UConn. If she has a normal season, she will blow past Tina Charles (2,346) midseason, leaving her behind only Maya Moore (3,036).  - JOHN ALTAVILLA

(Don McPeak / USA Today Sports) See more galleries Caption UConn Men: The Free Agents Have Arrived Brad Horrigan / The Hartford Courant UConn has had good experiences with fifth-year transfers, but this season takes it to a new level. The Huskies have added two players, Sterling Gibbs, left, and Shonn Miller, who are not only experienced players and college graduates, but standout players from their respective leagues, Gibbs from Seton Hall and the Big East, Miller from Cornell and the Ivy League. So they bring the feel of NBA free agents – proven players who should provide an immediate impact.Many of the experiences – the Husky Run, the grueling, four-hour first practice, the runs up cemetery hill – have been new for Gibbs, who had also played at Texas, and Miller. Both have experienced some form of First Night, but not the full-house, level of noise and electricity they will see Friday. So this will be another facet of the “UConn experience” for them. - DOM AMORE

(Brad Horrigan / The Hartford Courant) See more galleries First Night is coming Friday at Gampel Pavilion.
On the women's side, it’s almost certain to be the first in a number of amazing and overwhelming nights and days for UConn’s three-time defending national champions. Yes, the Huskies will be that good again.
On the men's side, following a tough season, the Huskies are looking to regain respectability. Though there are many newcomers, there are still enough players who were on the 2014 championship team and know how it feels to win – as well as the empty feeling of bowing out early last March and watching the madness from home.
To whet your appetite for Husky Hoops The Courant's John Altavilla and Dom Amore offer up five key points to ponder for each team. Remember, doors to Gampel open at 6 p.m. and the event is free and open to the public.
